Now ministers are set to use the time to fix problems in the system - but the programme wont be halted or scrapped.The documents also revealed that more help would be given to the self employed, and that the advance payments will be spread out and paid back over a longer amount of time.Last weekend ministers were forced to deny they were planning an emergency electionTheresa May’s deal fails to get passed in the Commons.Steven Saxby - Labour’s parliamentary candidate for the Cities of London and Westminster, told The Sun Online that he’s seen people in his area who are “terried” about going on to Universal Credit - and the issue could win Labour seats.“Universal Credit isn’t working for most people, it’s a slap in the face for poor and vulnerable working families in areas like Westminster,” he said.“It’s better to scrap it - people associate this toxic brand with something that’s cruel and harmful.”Ministers have insisted no one will be worse off going on to the new system when it’s rolled out for people who are on the old benefits next year.Those on housing benefit, child tax credits and job seekers’ allowance will be made to go onto Universal Credit in the coming months.If you are experiencing trouble applying for your Universal Credit, or the payments just dont cover it, here are your options:Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently , or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.The new system aims to simply the Department for Work and Pensions, and give all claimants one single monthly payment.But Tory MPs are already rebelling about the rollout - after it emerged that millions could be £ a month worse off after the switch.The Government has promised £ billion worth of transitional protections, but it’s not known how long that cash will last.A group of MPs - led by architect of Universal Credit, Iain Duncan Smith, wants Philip Hammond to plough an extra £billion into the system in the upcoming Budget to offset the cuts introduced by George Osborne.

title: brexit deal theresa may cabinet meeting
story: The PM spent nearly three hours laying out her strategy to the rest of the Cabinet after rumours ministers were prepared to quit.And she served up bacon, sausage and egg sandwiches to the warring team - in a jokey reference to the pizza party eight ministers hosted last night.Mrs May told the Cabinet: Im convinced thatwe as a Government stand together and stand firm we can achieve this.A No spokesman insisted no ministers threatened to resign in protest against the PMs Brexit plans.But Mrs May is still fighting off a rebellion from her DUP allies - as they threaten to block her domestic agendashe doesnt accept their demands on Brexit.Tomorrow the PM will travel to Brussels where she will make the case for her Chequers plan in front of other EU leaders.Today senior Eurocrats Michel Barnier and Donald Tusk both said a deal is unlikely to be struck this week and called on the UK side to break the deadlock.Mr Barnier said: We must find a solution to ensure that there is no hard border in any circumstance on the island of Ireland. We are not there yet.Several subjects remain open, including Ireland. We need more time to find this global agreement and achieve the decisive progress we need to finalise this negotiation on Britains orderly withdrawal.We will take this time, calmly and seriously, to find this global agreement in the next weeks.And Mr Tusk added: Unfortunately, the report on the state of negotiations that I got from Michel Barnier today, as well as yesterdays debate in the House of Commons, give me no grounds for optimism before tomorrows European Council summit on Brexit.As I see it, the only grounds for hope for a deal for now is the goodwill and determination on both sides. However, for a breakthrough to take place we need more than goodwill, we need new facts.Tomorrow I am going to ask Prime Minister Mayshe has concrete proposals on how to break the impasse. Only such proposals can determinea breakthrough is possible.Last night, a group of eight senior ministers met over spicy meat pizza to air their frustration about the PM.The ministers who gathered in Andrea Leadsoms office included Michael Gove, Jeremy Hunt, Dominic Raab and Liz Truss.They reportedly agreed they should continue backing Mrs May as she battles to fight off Brussels attempts to carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Penny Mordaunt, the International Development Secretary who attended the meeting, said today: No one is planning on resigning. We are all doing our jobs and we are trying to get the best deal for this country, and thats it.BREXITEERS will never be forgiven for making  promises to the British people, John Major claimed tonight.The former PM insisted the UKs vote to quit the EU was a colossal misjudgement - saying those who campaigned for it have much to answer for.And he blasted Boris Johnson for undermining Theresa Mays efforts to secure a Brexit deal.In a speech in London this evening, Sir John said: We know the post-Brexit world will be very dferent from now.It cannot be otherwise, because no form of Brexit will remotely match up to the promises made by the Leave campaign in the referendum - they were vote-gathering fantasies, not serious politics.It will damage our national and personal wealth, and may seriously hamper our future security. It may even, over time, break up our United Kingdom. It will most definitely limit the prospects of our young.And - once this becomes clear - I believe those who promised what will never be delivered will have much to answer for. They persuaded a deceived population to vote to be weaker and poorer.That will never be forgotten - nor forgiven.The former Tory leader is now campaigning for a second referendum on Brexit to overturn the result of the  vote.Labour MP Virendra Sharma, a backer of the pro-EU Best for Britain campaign, mocked the ministers for failing to launch a challenge to the PM.He said: After days of briefing about their plot we expected these Brexiteers to give the Prime Minister a pizza their mind. It seems like they folded quicker than a calzone.And Tory backbenchers have denied they want to force Mrs May out of office.Steve Baker, the Brexiteers shop steward, admitted: “There really isn’t time for a long leadership contest. And there aren’t the Eurosceptic numbers to change Prime Minister.”But Mrs May could face a tougher challenge from the DUP, which is propping up her majority in Parliament.Nigel Dodds, the partys leader in Westminster, said thatshe tries to put a border in the Irish Sea the DUP will say: How can we continue implement your domestic agenda, your budgets and everything  He added: Under the Fixed-Term Parliaments Act there are a lot of things that we can not support in terms of the government’s domestic and financial and welfare agenda which does not trigger the possibility of Jeremy Corbyn coming into No.”This week European leaders warned that No Deal is closer than ever after talks between officials broke down on Sunday night.But Mrs Mays ministers have insisted that eventhere isnt a Brexit deal this week, one could be struck at a special summit next month.The respected peer called on the PM to start building lorry parks and drawing up customs forms so that Britain is ready for disruption at our borders.Lord Hague also said Mrs May should consider ripping up the blueprint for Brexit negotiations - and consider signing up to the European Economic Area for the next three years.He warned the Tories are at breaking point as MPs row over whether or not to back the PM as she heads to Brussels for talks with European leaders.The former Foreign Secretary said: It is now essential to turn up to full throttle the preparations for leaving without a deal.Yes, that sadly means everything from printing customs forms to building lorry parks in Kent.A No Deal Brexit is extremely undesirable, and might be prevented by Parliament, but since it could happen it has to be prepared for psychologically and politically, not just logistically.He added that fresh thinking - which could include adopting an EEA solution to give the Government more time to negotiate a deal - could help Mrs May shore up her position.

title: new photos sunken british tanks d day
story: The war tanks sunk during Operation Smash - a huge training exercise held on a Dorset beach in April , just weeks ahead of the Normandy landings.Six lives were lost during the drill - but a lesson was learnt so that, on D-Day, British and Canadian tanks were launched in shallow water.Nick Reed from The Isle of Purbeck Sub Aqua Club, which has launched a project to map the history of the seven sunken tanks, said the six soldiers lost did not die in vain.Everybody says that Operation Smash was an absolute, complete disaster, said Nick.Well,  tanks were launched and seven sank, so that means  got to shore in this exercise and from that the British learnt a lesson.So when the British and Canadians launched their tanks on D-Day, they didnt launch theirs offshore because it was too rough.Whereas the Americans launched theirs five kilometres offshore.The result of the American decision is well-known - just two of the  tanks initially deployed to storm Omaha beach made it ashore.Omaha would be the bloodiest of the D-Day beaches.If we hadnt got armoured support ashore on D-Day, our troops may not have established a beach head, said Mr Reed.So in many ways the sacrice of those six guys may have changed the course of World War Two - thats the way we like to think of it.Their sacrice wasnt in vain, things were learnt from it and maybe that contributed to the success of D-Day.Conditions at the e site off Studland Beach are notoriously changeable, making the sunken tanks a challenge to photograph.The new images of them are thought to be the clearest ever taken.Paul Pettitt, who photographed the wrecks with his we Alison, said: Its rough as you like.Those pictures were done over the course of a whole summer. Some days we went down and werent able to get anything.The worst problem is the wind direction which kicks up the silt and sand on the bottom, and makes it go very gloomy down there.But we got a lucky break one day when we got some really clear visibility and were able to get these pictures.The tanks have also taken on new lives as articial reefs.Theyre absolutely full of wildle, said Mr Reed.There are several big conger eels living in one of the main tanks, theres crabs, theres lobsters, theres big shoals of fish that swim around them.Thats almost like a commemoration of the men themselves - men died on these tanks but these tanks now are providing le to the marine animals around the area.The Duplex Drive Valentine tanks were equipped with a buoyant canvas screen which could be raised up around the tank and sat above the water line.But soon after the tanks were launched the wind changed and water started to sweep over the top of the screens.They were launched in suitable conditions but the wind blew up just after they were launched, said Mr Reed.The skirts, which provided the buoyancy, were only about a metre above the water - and obviously what keeps water out will keep water in.So I think most of them were swamped and sank.Earlier this year, a man believed to be the last-surviving soldier from Operation Smash - who is also a crew member from one of the doomed tanks - was located.Albert Price, , is now living in the West Midlands.Its hoped hell be able to attend a  year commemoration of Operation Smash next year.

title: terrified mum posts 50 an hour job ad for someone to take her kids trick or treating on halloween

title: royal wedding princess eugenie wedding soap opera
story: Too much décolletage or, God forbid, a side split and one risks what has now become known in common parlance as “doing a Raquel Welch”, who didn’t so much upstage the bride at her son’s ­wedding as eclipse her completely.And so, paralysed by the uncertainty of it all, the majority of “immediate family” wedding snaps feature the loving couple, a couple of blokes chilling in their usual suits, and two middle-aged women looking deeply uncomfortable in unforgiving taffeta and a hat that resembles an upturned lamp shade.Or, in Sarah Ferguson’s case, a titfer reminiscent of a stewardess for a s Eastern Bloc airline. Then, to keep up appearances for the family photo, Sarah had to hover nervously behind the gimlet-eyed former father-in-law who has ignored her for the past  years.But worst of all, she had to stand by and watch Prince Harry and his glossy new we sweep in and steal bride Eugenie’s thunder with news of their impending baby.A child, I might add, with the added sting of bumping the bride and her sister Beatrice even further down the line of succession.Far from feeling like a “royal wedding”, it bore all the hallmarks of a Hello! or OK!-funded celebrity shindig, or worse, an excerpt from US prime-time soap opera The Royals, starring Elizabeth Hurley.Take the, er, crowds gathered outside Windsor’s St George’s Chapel.“Who are you hoping to catch a glimpse of ” asked a TV reporter.“George Clooney,” came the cheerful reply.Someone  was hoping for David Beckham. They got neither.Both couples claimed other commitments but, given that they all took centre stage at Harry and Meghan’s nuptials and the Beckhams also made the cut for William and Kate’s big day, perhaps they felt this wasn’t A-list enough Instead, we had to make do with, among others, models Naomi Campbell, Cara ­Delevingne and Kate Moss, X Factor judges Robbie Williams and Ayda Field, and actresses Demi Moore and Liv Tyler.Some of whom uploaded gushing videos from the event and Instagram photos of their outfits with hashtag plugs for ­ious clothing brands.At a “royal” wedding  The notoriously traditional Queen Mother must be turning in her grave.There will be the modernisers within the palace walls who regard this as “progress” for a monarchy that, as they see it, must appeal to a younger generationit is to survive.But to my mind, it’s the complete opposite.The pomp, ceremony, tradition, duty and, most importantly, ­mystique of the royals is what sustains them.This wedding — between a “Princess” who performs no royal duties and her Jack of tequila trade — has shone a ­spotlight on the blindingly obvious threat that, once the dutul Queen and Prince Philip are no longer with us, the ­“modern” monarchy will continue to make ever decreasing circles until the taxpayer finally decides, “Hang on — they’re just like us” and the game will be up.With this #royalwedding where even the bride’s mother, left, Instagrammed a designer plug “for my amazing dress” that threat has just come one step closer.RITA ORA is promoting her new album Phoenix. “It’s my first global release of an album.I’m really excited to express my music to the world,” she says.But why the seemingly ­regular need to, er, express her breasts at the same time After all, Ed Sheeran has never posed in just his kecks and he’s sold  squillion records.ANGRY passengers on a flight from London Heathrow to Istanbul intervened to stop Home Office officials from deporting Somalian Yaqub Ahmed.“I know he’s scared,” protested one, before leading a chant of: “Take him off the plane, take him off the plane.”Though probably not as scared as the -year-old girl who was gang-raped in London by Ahmed and two of his equally unsavoury friends – the crime for which he was being deported before these witless do-gooders stepped in.Pitully, the officials capitulated and Ahmed is still in this country awaiting our next move.Meanwhile, as some of the passengers virtue-signalled their liberal credentials by posting footage of the showdown, perhaps they could now be identied and charged with obstructing the course of justice Or, at the very least, be asked to welcome the delightful Mr Ahmed into their own homes until such time as his removal can be rearranged Let’s seetheir liberalism extends to putting their own teenage daughters at risk.PIZZAS and pies must shrink to tackle obesity, claim new official guidelines from Public Health England.Sigh. Amazing, isn’t it, how millions of people manage to stay slim by eating healthily and doing moderate exercise while advocating the same mindset to their children Radical, I know, buta pizza is large, how about sharing it Or perhaps not buying it at all Or is a slice of personal responsibility too hard to swallow CHANNING Tatum and Jessie J are dating.We know this because they’ve been spotted ­laughing together at a mini-golf course.Ah yes, those heady, early months of dating when you’re presenting the best side of yourself and pretending you just love doing kooky stuff like ­hitting a ball into the clown’s mouth or paddling in pointless circles around the local ­boating lake.Then the eager-to-please phase passes and, before you know it, you’re watching ­separate TV shows in dferent parts of the house. And what a blessed relief it is too.QUESTION Time is holding a series of auditions for potential David Dimbleby replacements such as Kirsty Wark, Emily Maitlis, Nick Robinson and Julie Etchingham.They are each chairing a  of politicians and journalists in front of a live audience – the only dference being the programmes won’t be broadcast.Meaning that every last one will be far better than the real thing where, with a few notable exceptions, participants now sanitise their every utterance for fear of being publicly mauled by the kangaroo court of social media.GWYNETH  Paltrow and her new husband Brad Falchuk now refer to them- selves as “The Faltrows”. Let’s just hope that German ice skater Paul Boll doesn’t take a shine to Jane Horrocks.THE SUN has ­partnered with the Movember Foundation to help raise funds and awareness for men’s health issues by ­encouraging people to grow a sponsored ­moustache.Count me in.Post-menopause, this is the look I’m aiming for.AN “invisible” super-yacht has been invented for ­billionaires who value their privacy.Costing £million, it is coated in mirrored glass which, according to the designer, makes it “disappear between water and sea”.Er, doesn’t that mean other vessels will smash into it Still, at least it will sink ­privately. KATE SILVERTON asks her six-year-old daughter each day: “How did you fail today ”The Strictly contestant, who advocates taking kids outside their comfort zone by trying boxing or climbing, adds: “You are not ­trying hard enoughyou haven’t failed.”Perhaps give skying a miss though, eh ANT McPARTLIN and estranged we Lisa ­Armstrong received their decree nisi yesterday.Meaning that in six weeks’ time, the petitioner can apply for the decree absolute as long as everyone is agreed on the ision of cash and assets.In other words – as anyone who’s orced will know – this is when the arguments really begin.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl baked cookies grandmothers ashes inside
story: The unnamed schoolgirl is reported to have been openly telling students what she had added to her recipe.A male classmate from the Da Vinci Charter Academy High School in Calornia told Fox how she was passing the biscuits out.He said: “This girl is going around telling everyone, basically at this point, that she had brought these cookies to school with human ashes in them.”The boy, who is not being named, was then questioned by school administrators over fears he may have eaten one of the biscuits.He told Fox he was asked to sign a statement and then not tell anyone about what happened.His parents were furious and accused the school covering up the alleged baking disaster and failed inform them of that happened.His mother said: “It blew my mind. I was really repulsed and I was upset that I wasn’t even notied.”The father added: “The district seems to be a little bit more concerned about protecting themselves than protecting their students.”Police have confirmed that there is an investigation and they are working to confirmtwo students were behind the alleged morbid plan.At least nine students were given the biscuits, but there are no reports of anyone falling ill.Lt. Paul Doroshov with the Davis Police Department told KVOR: “I have not heard of anyone getting sick or anybody being harmed as far as physically, physiologically by this.It is unclearthe biscuits actually contained human remains, but ABC have said test results are pending.On Monday, the Davis Joint Unied School District released a statement.A spokesman said: “While we cannot comment on confidential student matters, I can tell you that the physical and social-emotional safety of our students is our first priority.“We take all allegations of wrongdoing seriously and we conduct thorough investigations and involve the police when appropriate.“This case has been particularly challenging and we have responded appropriately and in the most respectful and dignied way possible.

title: 600 children harmed uk charities
story: The bombshell Charity Commission report discovered that kids represented nearly HALF of all sexual harassment, bullying and other serious safeguarding incidents where a victim was identied.Charities submitted a total of , reports of serious cases relating to safeguarding incidents since the Oxfam sex abuse scandal erupted in February - a third higher than the whole of last year.This is equivalent to ten serious incidents every single day. And only . per cent of registered charities in the UK submitted any kind of serious incident to the charity watchdog’s interim ‘safeguarding taskforce’ report published last night.The damning findings lay bare the scale of abuse in the charity sector, which has been rocked by allegations of sexual misconduct since it emerged Oxfam and Save the Children had covered up allegations for years.In cases where a victim was identied,  were children - equivalent to . per cent, with many of the cases relating to sexual abuse. Other examples of harm included bullying, physical abuse and a car crash,A third of the victims reported between February  and September  were adults, while the remainder couldn’t identy an inidual victim.Nine in ten of alleged perpetrators were connected to the charity in question. Just  incidents found no connection with the charity.The worst offending charities were in the foreign aid sector, which accounted for three in ten of the incidents. Disability and religious-related charities accounted for  per cent each.And in a sign the true scale of abuse could be even higher, the Charity Commission warned that there is “signicant and systemic underreporting of incidents by charities working at home and abroad”.Only , of the country’s , charities submitted any kind of serious incident report since  and just . per cent of charities have reported a safeguarding incident in that period.The Charity Commission’s head of policy, planning and communications Sarah Atkinson said: “The public rightly expect charities to demonstrate the highest standards of ethical behaviour and attitude.“That includes taking action when something has gone badly wrong, or when there’s been a near miss.“Making a serious incident report to the Commission is not in itself an admission of wrongdoing or failure. Quite the reverse: it demonstrates that a charity is responding properly to incident or concern.“So we welcome the increase in reporting by some charities, especially international aid charities that appear to have improved their reporting since February’s revelations.“But we’re not convinced that we’re seeing everything we should be. Working with charities, we need to bring about a culture change on reporting to ensure charities are safe places, better able to make a dference to people’s lives.”The news of the figures comes as the launch of a new  database of suspected ­sexual predators working in the charity sector is to be  announced tomorrow.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: london paddington rail delays major disruptions
story: All Great Western Railwaytrains between Paddington and Slough are expected to be suspended until at least midday today after overhead cables were damaged.National Rail has said TfL Rail services will be suspended until at least pm today.There is no service in either direction on the Heathrow Express due to the overhead power supply problems.Transport for London tweeted this morning: Due to damage to the overhead electrical wires there is no service on TfL Rail btw Paddington and Heathrow.Ticket acceptance is in place on local buses and London Underground. We are working closely with Network Rail to restore services as quickly as possible.National Rail added: Yesterday evening the overhead electric wires near Ealing Broadway were severely damaged. As a result of this, trains are unable to run to and from London Paddington.Network Rail are working to recover all the stranded trains and to recty the damage to the overhead electric wires.Network Rail expect to reopen  of the  lines from midday.However trains will remain disrupted until the end of the day.Rail replacement buses are operating between London Paddington and Heathrow Airport.Travellers have already expressed their frustration, with one writing on Twitter: When you get up at : to catch the early train to London and get to the station to be told Paddington Station is closed! #wednesdaymorning #tired #backtotheofficeAnother added: Probably the worst day ive had this year. Never ever trusting GWR, TfL Rail and Paddington Station again in my le.GWR said trains were stranded on the line between Paddington and Reading, adding: Owing to the extent of the damage, no trains are expected to be able to operate between London Paddington and Hayes  Harlington in either direction for much of Wednesday.As a result, GWR, TfL Rail and Heathrow Express will not be operating a train service between London Paddington, Hayes  Harlington or Slough until such time as repairs have been completed.Officials have warned most trains will start and terminate at Reading, with a reduced train service operating between Reading and Slough.No trains will operate between Slough and London Paddington.National Rail has told those travelling to London from beyond Reading to not go to Paddington but instead travel straight to either London Waterloo, London Marylebone or London Euston.British Transport Police confirmed they were assisting Network Rail with the overhead line issue.

newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Donald Trump ’s motormouth enemy Michael Moore is noisily dejected.Angry because a US President he compares to Adolf Hitler and accuses of displaying an unhealthy sexual interest in his own daughter is in the White House But this week, Moore’s also unhappy with the pound-a-night, five-star Mayfair hotel in London he’s billeted in. Oh, and Brexit’s one of the craziest moves he’s heard of. “I’m depressed because I’m sleeping on a futon in a damp country with warm beer and a public that wants to leave Europe, when there would be no Europe without you,” propounds the outspoken filmmaker. “Twice in the past century you offered up hundreds of thousands of lives so that there would be a Europe. “You know, you don’t get to leave. It’s only there because of your sacrice and out of gratitude the rest of Europe said your language will be the language of Europe. Sorry French. “Europe looks up to Britain, is grateful to Britain for saving Europe, then you just wake up one day and say, ‘we’re leaving’. What was so wrong ”  Moore, half an hour late and looking ashe’s just climbed out of that futon, rants about the many reasons there could be for Brexit, from fishing quotas to controlling our borders. “Just say, we’re f***ing Britain... for Christ’s sake. We only have one cuisine and it’s fish and chips...” is his negotiating stance on quotas. Ruling out taxation as a reason to go, Moore explodes rhetorically again. “And don’t say it’s immigration because you had a f***ing empire and you’ve had people of colour and people from other countries throughout your entire Commonwealth,” he screams. “If you don’t like it, get rid of the Commonwealth and stop playing those stupid games every two or four years.” Picking the bones out of his shystatements on British politics is trickier than dissecting his US positions. Moore hates Trump, absolutely detests the President. Can he think of a single good thing to say about the Oval Office’s orange resident  “No.”  Trump and Brexit are twin outrages he brackets together. “You have a dumbed-down public – and you can say the same thing about this country too,” is his stinging verdict. The Oscar winner’s new movie about his nemesis, Fahrenheit   – that date taken from the November day after Trump’s shock victory over Hillary Clinton in  – is brutal. This isn’t just the cinema case for Trump’s prosecution. Moore’s the judge and jury who finds the President guilty of crimes against the American people. “He only believes in Donald J Trump. His whole ideology is Trump, so a malignant narcissist is the most dangerous person to have as the leader of any country because everything goes through the filter of ‘how does this affect me, is it good for me ’, not is it good for the people of this country.” Moore also effectively accuses the President of incestuous paedophile tendencies over uncomfortable past behaviour with daughter Ivanka – now a White House aide. “I feel bad for her... evennothing happened, it’s a form of child sexual abuse to go on TV and say the thing you have most in common with your daughter is sex or thatshe weren’t my daughter I’d be dating her,” snorts Moore. “Or he says ‘hi’ to a -year-old and then when she’s out of earshot he says, ‘I’m going to be dating her in  years’.”  The Left-wing crusader argues, correctly, that almost any other figure in public le would be out of a job and probably in courtthey said half the sleazy comments uttered by Trump. “The law says a teacher must reporta child, a student, comes to them and says my dad keeps sayingI wasn’t his daughter he would be dating me, my dad says the thing we most have in common is sex. Here’s a picture of my dad making me sit on his lap and kissing him,” Moore states. “If you showed that to a teacher,a -year-old girl showed that to a teacher, the teacher’s required by law to report that particular inidual to child-protection services. Andyou do not, you could be arrested, as a teacher, on felony charges.” Trump’s speeches lip-synced over Hitler is central to a warning from Moore that the US constitution may no more protect Americans from a tyrannical president than Germany’s saved them from the Nazi leader. “I don’t say Trump was Hitler, I implied Hitler could’ve been Trump –it’s Trump’s voice coming out of Hitler’s mouth, not the other way around,” he says. “I didn’t paint a little moustache on Trump. I took Hitler and defamed him by having Trump coming out of his mouth.” The attack is intensied by accusing an increasingly authoritarian President of fascism. “The fascism of the st Century will not come with concentration camps and swastikas. It will come with a smiley face and a TV show,” Moore says, drawing on the study Friendly Fascism by US professor Bertram Gross.  He invests almost supernatural powers in how well Trump knows his support base. “The whole Stormy Daniels thing, he leaked it. Here’s how smart he is. “His approval ratings had gone down to the low s. Sixty Minutes [an influential US TV show] does the story on Stormy Daniels and, since then, his approval ratings have gone up. He knows his base, he knows that % of white men who voted for him, when they hear he got to have sex with a porn star, doesn’t think that’s a bad thing – that’s a good thing!” The Apprentice  “The beauty of that show and why people liked Trump is that, every week, he got to fire the jerk that you work with at the Daily Mirror. “Everybody works with that jerk and so the fantasy of that show is shyimaginingsomebody could just say to that person, ‘you’re fired’. “That’s why people liked that show– because they know that person. That person’s working down the hall or in the next cubicle.” Moore’s previous films challenged official views: Fahrenheit   on terrorism, Sicko about medical care, while Bowling for Columbine explored how the US gun culture murders tshyhousands of Americans.  He’s aware moaning about the futon and the hotel are first-world problems – genuine anger spiced with a little teasing. In the new film, Moore is hopeful a new generation of grassroots campaigners will defeat Trump. Yesterday, however, he was morose, defeatist. “Hoping for impeachment, hoping for the special prosecutor to indict him – stop hoping, it isn’t going to happen. “If you haven’t figured it out by now, that this guy out-smarted everybody and got into the White House,” admits Moore, . And he confesses: “I’m not in a hopeful place right now, but that’s only because I recognise the seriousness of the situation, how dire our situation is.” The fight is still there, but Moore, the crumpled crusader, recognises this war is far from won. title: john major speech full ex
story: NewsJohn Major speech in full: Ex-PM warns Brexiteers they will never be forgotten - or forgivenThe former Tory Prime Minister said Brexiteers “persuaded a deceived population to vote to be weaker and poorer”ShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Major has branded Brexit a ‘colossal misjudgement’ and warned it could lead to the break up of the UK in a blistering speech tonight. The former Tory Prime Minister said Brexiteers “persuaded a deceived population to vote to be weaker and poorer”. And he warned: “That will never be forgotten - or forgiven.”Sir John suggested leaving front line politics allowed him to look at Brexit without ambition, party loyalty or his constituents’ views clouding his judgement.His intervention comes just hours before Theresa May jets off to Brussels for a crucial summit with the remaining  EU leaders. Delivering the Michael Quinlan Lecture in Central London, he said: “I have made no  promises about Brexit that I must pretend can still be honoured, even though – in my heart – I know they cannot. “I am free to say absolutely and precisely what I believe about Brexit. And it is this: “I understand the motives of those who voted to leave the European Union: it can – as I well know – be very frustrating. He added: “Nonetheless, after weighing its frustrations and opportunities, there is no doubt in my own mind that our decision is a colossal misjudgement that will diminish both the UK and the EU. “It will damage our national and personal wealth, and may seriously hamper our future security. It may even, over time, break up our United Kingdom. It will most definitely limit the prospects of our young. “And – once this becomes clear – I believe those who promised what will never be delivered will have much to answer for. They persuaded a deceived population to vote to be weaker and poorer. “That will never be forgotten – nor forgiven.” Former Lib Dem leader Tim Farron said: John Major is right.The snake oil salesmen of Boris and Gove, the duo who sold the country a pup will never be forgiven. People trusted them and they betrayed that trust and Boris just stormed when it got dficult. He is now off in a huff to ruffle his hair in a corner.Now the Prime Minister is trying to get a deal, even a bad deal, through the ERG and DUP. She is now stuck between a rock and the ERG. John Major is correct, the public are being taken a ride for a few peoples ideological dream. This is the biggest disaster to befall Britain since Suez. Heres Sir John Majors lecture in full  When Mary Quinlan invited me to deliver this lecture I was flattered – and fearful flattered by the opportunity, and fearful about whether I could do justice to such a remarkable man. I first met Michael over  years ago and he left me with two over-riding impressions. First, he was an easy man to like and second, he was even easier to admire. He had a distinguished career as a civil servant, and – to me – exemplied the ideal of public service. It was my experience in Government that, taken as a whole, the best of the Civil Service was the equal of talent in every other sphere of activity and, in Michael’s case, he was not only a public servant – in the true sense of that term – he was also a world-class authority on his subject. Public service matters because, without it, Government is paralysed. Its efficiency is as relevant to public wellbeing as policy itself. This is not universally understood, but it should be: those who use “bureaucrat” as a term of abuse simply don’t understand the wider role of public servants. I hope to speak of this more fully at a later date but, for now, let me observe merely that the State needs its fair share of our brightest and best talent, and it is important we continue to attract them. Michael Quinlan is an exemplar of who and what we need. And, at this moment, our country is in need of all the expertise it can get. We live in a world of flux. Power structures are changing. Allegiances are changing. Little is as it was: even less will remain as it is.  For many millions, the financial crash of a decade ago destroyed their faith in the political and financial world. I am not surprised. The innocent were hurt. Since then, the global market, the on-rush of science, of medicine, and all forms of technological advance, continues to move the world on at an ever–faster pace. Government is a serious and complex business. It is far more important than the trivia of who is “up” and who is “down” in the political stakes – intriguing and newsworthy though that may be. Government is about enhancing our status in the world. Our security. Our economic wellbeing. Our national reputation. Our future prospects. It is about selecting priorities between Government programmes between business and civil society between rich and poor. It involves choices between competition and compassion between young and old or between the component parts of ourUnited Kingdom. Sometimes, the choices are straightforward but, all too often, they can be hideously complex. What Government is not about is cheap grandstanding. It’s not about deceiving the electorate with slogans, or soundbites, or untruths or half-truths. It’s not about windy oratory that says nothing. It’s not about simplistic solutions to intricate problems. It’s not about scapegoating one part of our population to earn the plaudits of another. And – most emphatically – it’s not about princelings fighting for the political crown of Premiership. Coded messages that shriek “I’m the One” are about as subtle as a punch on the nose. Such self-interest is politics at its least attractive. It does not deliver sound government. It destabilises Government. As a general rule, those whose focus is on self-advancement are rarely the most suitable to be entrusted with power. Talk of power moves me on to the post-Brexit role of diplomacy and the Foreign Office. Here – in the Locarno Room – I feel a little inhibited. I recall Harold Wilson speaking in the  Election and asking, as he moved to his peroration: “ … and why do I talk about the Royal Navy ” to be told by a heckler: “Because you’re in Chatham.”.  But I plead “Not Guilty” to that charge. I talk of diplomacy because it is vital to our national interests and, once we leave the EU, we will need to become ever more forceful in pressing those interests. The blunt truth is that – as a nation of  million – our voice is going to be less resonant than as a leading member of a Union of  million. We need, therefore, to compensate – as far as we can – by increasing our foreign policy capability. That must mean more proactive diplomacy. If we retreat solely to our own interests to Fortress Britain to our own national boundaries to the role of on-looker and not innovator – then greater isolation will surely lead to greater irrelevance. But being proactive requires an expansion of our Foreign Service capacity. As an internationalist, I believe such a posture is desirable in all circumstances. Post-Brexit, it will be essential. For decades, our foreign policy has been bolstered by our membership of the EU, and our closeness to the US. Now, we are on the verge of leaving the EU, while the US continues to move towards Asia-Pacic – and away from Europe and the UK. Until now, every US President I have known has considered our relevance to America to be enhanced by our membership of the European Union. Yet very soon – on our current course – we will no longer be able to argue from within the EU for Anglo-American beliefs in free trade open markets and strong defence. Our value – as an ally of America – will decline. Our friends, the Americans, are hard-headed about power. It is romantic folly to think otherwise. Be in no doubt –the UK can no longer serve America’s interests in Europe, she will look where for someone who can. Of course, our relationship won’t collapse: ties of blood, trade and security will remain. But the UK will be even more clearly America’s subordinate and dependent junior partner. No “s”, no “buts”: we will be less relevant. No-one should be bedazzled by folksy talk of our “special relationship”: it is becoming less “special” year by year. At this moment our country needs to focus on policy, not personality on substance, not show on the national interest, not ideology. Because decisions that must soon be taken will shape the futures of our children and grandchildren for many years to come. You will assume that I am referring to Brexit – and I am. But my concern runs far wider than that. However, first Brexit … For centuries, our State schemed and plotted to prevent all Europe uniting against us. Our Monarchs even married off their children and bribed our foreign adversaries in order to maintain alliances. Now, we have chosen to turn our back on all Europe. A long line of former Statesmen will be turning in their graves. Europe gone ….. America going.  We are told our future aim is to be “Global Britain”: that is certainly the right policy, but it is hardly new. It has been the reality for  years. What is new is that much of the world will now perceive Britain to be a middle-sized, middle-ranking nation that is no longer super-charged by its alliances. Suddenly, the world will be a little chillier. If the art of negotiation is to obtain what you seek, then the intention must be to give a little togain a lot more. Such a negotiation is dficult. It benefits from a trusting relationship. From goodwill. It is most likely to succeedrespect is evident on both sides. I cannot know how the Government has conducted negotiations in private with the European Union: very possibly they have met the tenets I have set out. But, eventhey have , belligerent noises-off – on a daily basis – have built up ill-will, and made the Prime Minister’s task even more dficult. We know the post-Brexit world will be very dferent from now. It cannot be otherwise, because no form of Brexit will remotely match up to the promises made by the Leave Campaign in the referendum: they were vote-gathering fantasies, not serious politics. I have no constituency vote clouding my view of Brexit. I have no ambition driving my support for it. I have no Party Whips demanding loyalty before conscience. I have made no  promises about Brexit that I must pretend can still be honoured, even though – in my heart – I know they cannot. I am free to say absolutely and precisely what I believe about Brexit.

story: NewseBay Halloween costumes from horror films like Saw sold for children as young as THREESlenderman, Chucky, Pennywise the Clown, Freddy Krueger, Billy the puppet from Saw and Jason Voorhees costumes are being sold for kids on the online auction siteShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe Slenderman case sparked a debate about childrens safety"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEvery Halloween there is usually at least one costume that comes under fire. And this year eBay are advertising a number of fancy dress options from violent horror films - for kids aged just three-years-old. Children sized costumes for Chucky, Pennywise the Clown, Freddy Krueger, Billy the puppet from Saw and Jason Voorhees are currently for sale on the online marketplace, despite the films being rated . One UK seller describes their Saw themed outfit, which costs from pound., as being perfect for Halloween or a movie themed fancy dress.  The childrens Zombie Cheerleader Girl costume from Warehouse Ltd costs from pound., and encourages youngsters to get ready to cheer on team dead. Meanwhile the Chucky-themed fancy dress from Johnnies Outlet shows an image of a child brandishing a kne. Also among the horror film themed costumes is a Slenderman outfit, a character which inspired a horror stabbing in the US. In , -year-old girls Morgan Geyser and Anissa Weier, kned Payton Leutner, also , in a forest in Waukesha City, Wisconsin. Leutner had been stabbed  times before she was found by a cyclist and rushed to the hospital, where she survived after a y recovery period.  Geyser and Weier claimed they had committed the crime to prove their loyalty to Slenderman who they thought was real, and did not want him to harm them or their families. Weier and Geyser told police they read about Slender Man on a website known as Creepypasta Wiki, where scary stories are submitted by users. It is depicted as resembling a thin, unnaturally tall man with a blank and usually featureless face, and wearing a black suit. The Slender Man is commonly said to stalk, abduct, or traumatise people, particularly children.  Also appearing on eBay are Harley Quinn costumes complete with hot pants and tummy baring tops for young girls. Others include a zombie cheerleader and schoolgirl costumes which show a lot of flesh. An eBay spokesman said: We have contacted our prohibited items team and they have reviewed all of these listings inidually.None of these items are restricted or illegal for sale in the UK.We serve only adult customers on our marketplace as eBay is an over s site. You need to be an adult to agree to the user agreements to sign up, and to purchase. Last year, American retailer Walmart came under fire for selling an Anne Frank costume for children, which was later removed due to backlash. And this year, website Jokers Masquerade have been criticised for its dirty old man costume, which has been slammed by sex attack victims who describe it as offensive and triggering.

story: NewsHow hands-on Meghan Markle is showing Prince Harry how to be a modern member of new royal family with PDAsThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex cuddled waiting schoolchildren while one little boy even stroked Harrys beard as they kicked off day two in DubboShareCommentsByNatalie EvansRussell MyersAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video adorable-moment-little-boy-strokes-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex showed how they are shaping the modern-day Royal Family with a very public display of affection in Australia. The couple received a huge hug from little Luke Vincent, who came to greet them from Buninyong School in New South Wales. He got a hug from Meghan and then Harry bent down to speak to him and Luke didnt give him any choice! she said. Lukes favourite person in the world is Santa Claus, who has a beard. So he rubbed Harrys beard. Its been a wonderful experience for these little country kids to meet people theyve only ever seen on TV. Meghan and Harrys Royal Tour so far in pictures as Duke and Duchess begin day two in Australia Meghan is wearing Aussie label Outlander jeans, a shirt by Maison Kitsune, boots by J Crew, a jacket from the Serena Williams collection and an Aussie label Natalie Martin necklace. Their first engagement of the day will see them meet representatives of the Royal Flying Doctors Service- who travel across Australia delivering vital and often urgent medical care to those living in remote parts of the country. The Duke and Duchess will attend the naming dedication and unveiling of a new aircraft in the RFDS fleet as part of celebrations for  years of delivering healthcare to those in need. During their walk through the hangar they will have an opportunity to meet with local RFDS health workers and community members who have benefited from the important work.  The Australian RFDS was the world’s first flying doctors service. Day two of the Royal Tour comes as Australia remains gripped by Royal baby fever, according to local media. Meghan and Harry made the pregnancy announcement shortly after landing in Australia to begin their first oversees tour as a married couple. In a tweet sent out by Kensignton Palace, the announcement read: Their Royal Highnesses The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are very pleased to announce that The Duchess of Sussex is expecting a baby in the Spring of .  Speaking yesterday morning , a senior Palace source said: “Everyone is hugely excited about the news. The whole of the family are very happy they were all able to congratulate the couple in person before they left for their first major overseas tour. Meghan’s mum Doria Ragland , who lives in Los Angeles, Calornia, is said to very happy about this lovely news - while Thomas Markle reportedly found out from his ex-we as opposed to hearing the news from Meghan. A Palace spokesperson added that the proud mother is looking forward to welcoming her first grandchild. The Royal Tour includes  days of around  engagements - some of which have been carefully tailored with Meghans pregnancy in mind. Parts of the tour include a visit to Fiji and Tonga - areas affected by Zika, a virus which is harmful to pregnant woman and can cause borth deformities.  Despite this, the Duchess of Sussex will travel to Fiji - but is is under strict orders to stay away from rainforests and jungles on Pacic islands. The virus is a “moderate” risk on both islands. A palace source said: “They sought out top medical advice.” Zika is transmitted by mosquitoes, which feed between dusk and dawn. Official advice states: “Pregnant women should consider postponing non-essential travel until after the pregnancy.” But we can reveal organisers have created an itinerary that will let Meghan forgo outside events at the crucial times and stay away from more prevalent areas, such as rural environments. A senior palace source said Harry and Meghan have spoken to doctors.

title: its not wrong feel joy
story: NewsopinionIt’s not wrong to feel joy over royal baby amid Brexit gloom, says Eva SimpsonThere’s a lot to be said for good news that brings everyone together. There’s nothing wrong with feeling happy for Harry and MeghanShareCommentsByEva Simpson:,  OCT NewsopinionPrince Harry and Meghan "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Brexit gets more gloomy, complicated and depressing, how lovely of Prince Harry and Meghan to cheer us all up with the sweet news they’re expecting their first child in the spring. Talk about great timing. There’s nothing like a royal baby to put everyone – well, most people – in a good mood, evenit is just for a day or two. It gets people talking to each other, something we don’t do enough of these days as we rush about with our busy lives. Inevitably, some commentators have made much of the fact the baby will be the first mixed-race child to have “royal blood”. To hear them speak you’d think they were discussing an episode of Game of Thrones.  In the two years the couple have been together they’ve done so much to reposition the image of monarchy that the idea of a royal baby born with an African-American grandmother doesn’t seem as far-fetched as it would have been years ago. I asked most of my black friends and family what they thought about the announcement. All were excited about the news, even the men. One even declared “the fairlytale continues”. What did they think about the fact the baby will be of mixed race heritage  Not one of them cared. They were more excited about Prince Harry becoming a dad. If May’s royal wedding showed us anything, it was that this is a thoroughly modern couple who embrace all aspects of each other’s backgrounds. Andanyone’s worried about the new arrival being cut off from his or her cultural background, just remember the little one will be doted on by graceful grannie Doria Ragland. If she is able to pass on to her grandchild some of the values she instilled in Meghan when raising her, she’ll have done a great job. Of course, the trolls have come out in force – some of the comments and tweets are just ridiculous. Why can’t people just be happy for them

title: man booker prize winner anna
story: NewsMan Booker Prize winner: Anna Burns becomes first UK-born winner to claim coveted award in six yearsBelfast-born Burns fourth novel has become the first Northern Irish winner of the Man Booker Prize for her experimental tale of sexual coercion, MilkmanShareCommentsByLaura ForsythCraig Simpson:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAnna Burns on stage at the Guildhall in London after she was awarded the Man Booker Prize "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAnna Burns has been named as the winner of the this years Man Booker Prize, making her the first author from Northern Ireland to win the title. Her novel Milkman, tells the story of an -year-old girls encounters with sex, sectarianism and social coercion in an unnamed province. Burns is the first UK-born winner of the prize since Hilary Mantel in  and the th woman to win in the Man Bookers -year history. Welcomed as a novel that will help people think about Me Too, it has also been praised for a unique first-person voice rich in the conversational language of Northern Ireland and its handling of universal problems facing women and outsiders. Judges have said they did not consider the current prominence of Northern Ireland or the gender equality debate in their deliberations, nor was the accessibility of the book to average readers on the Tube. Milkman has been hailed as a book that will last by the chairman of the  of judges, philosopher Kwame Anthony Appiah, who said the novel was as useful for thinking about fractured societies in Lebanon and Syria as it was for the current gender debate in the West.  The chairman said he was resigned to the novel being linked to the Me Too movement, but said the work was more universal. Appiah said at a ceremony at the Guildhall in London: It speaks to the future. I think its going to last. I think this will help people to think about Me Too. Its not just about something that is going on in this moment. This is about the way in which men and women put pressure on a young girl to do things sexually that she doesnt want to do. It had to do with a masculine environment. This is particular, but its brilliantly universal. Its in the context of a sectarian, ided society. Milkman charts the course of a young girl with an ambivalent attitude to the paramilitary violence around her, struggling to combat unwanted sexual advances and the pernicious power of gossip.  Belfast-born Burns fourth novel uses a first-person voice rich in the conversational language of Northern Ireland, although the setting is never made explicit in the work. Lack of paragraphing adds a challenge for the reader. Questioned on whether the work was too challenging for the average reader, Appiah defended the choice saying: I have never thought that being readable on the Tube was an important feature of a novel. Crime writer Val McDermid, critic Leo Robson, writer and critic Jacqueline Rose and graphic novelist Leanne Shapton were the other judges for this years prize. Issues of Brexits impact on Northern Ireland and the cultural awareness of gender issues did not play a role in their choice of winner, the chair has confirmed. Appiah said: I would not have said guyswe dont pick a woman were going to get in trouble for this. Samewe were drting towards picking a man. We were not thinking about it. I really think this is a very original novel. We had never read anything like this before.  Its written in an amazing voice. This is a book about more than one thing. It is about many things. Its quite amazing. Appiah said the s deliberations had been friendly and the decision entirely unanimous, adding that there was no need for a vote and the choice was clear for the judges. Milkman was selected from a shortlist including youngest shortlisted writer, Daisy Johnson with Everything Under, Richard Powers The Overstory, Esi Edugyans Washington Black, Rachel Kushners The Mars Rooms and Robin Robertsons The Long Take. Burns victory ends a two-year streak by American winners of the prize, with talent from the US dominating since the award was opened up to writers from across the Atlantic in .

title: meghan markle hailed role model
story: NewsMeghan Markle hailed role model by Aboriginal schoolgirls as Prince Harry discusses mental health with pupilsAboriginal schoolgirls said seeing Meghan, a bi-racial, American orcee, being welcomed into the Royal Family shows anyone can be acceptedShareCommentsByRussell MyersAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video meghan-chats-group-dubbo-schoolgirls-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Meghan Markle has been hailed as an inspirational role model by schoolgirls in a small Australian town.The Duchess of Sussex was mobbed with Prince Harry when excited students came out to see them today despite torrential rains in Dubbo,  miles west of Sydney. The royal couple were visiting Dubbo Senior College to see the work of the Clontarf Foundationand the Girls’ Academy, nationwide programmes that improves the educational outcomes of young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. The students said how inspirational it was to meet “role model” Meghan. Kieasha Ross, , said: “Us being Aboriginal girls and her being of a dferent race and being accepted into the royal family shows us anyone can be accepted. “It’s great that someone who’s bi-racial and American can do this [marry into the Royal Family]. “It makes her a role model.”  As Harry and Meghan arrived, the heavens opened. They were first given a traditional “Acknowledgement of Country” greeting by Tiarnie McBride, , and John Hill, , whose grandfather is one of the most respected Aboriginal elders in Dubbo. Then the couple ided their time, with Harry meeting the boys of the Clontarf Academy, which uses sport to encourage kids to stay at school longer, while Meghan went to meet the girls in one of their classrooms. As she entered, all the girls giggled nervously and said: “Oh she’s so beautul!” “I’m very happy to be here” beamed Meghan.  Student Shakira McGrath-Nolan, , showed Meghan a photo wall with the girls on ious trips and doing sport. Then she showed her the girls’ attendance chart for the year with every girls’ name on the board and their attendance record. Shakira got slightly nervous and stumbled over her words, so the Duchess reassured her with a pat and rub of her back. “You’re doing great, keep going” she said softly.  Later Shakira said: “I was so nervous but she told me ‘You’ll be alright’ and that made me feel better. “She’ll be a great mum. “She’s so pretty!”. Another student showed her the Girls’ Academy logo ‘Develop a girl, Change a Community’. Meghan laughed: “That’s speaking my language” she said. She then sat down with six of the teenagers to chat about their hopes and aspirations. The week is spearheaded by the Miscarriage Association, which works with more than  charities to raise awareness amongst the public, healthcare professionals and parliamentarians of the key issues affecting those who have lost a baby.  Pregnancy and Infant Loss Remembrance Day is an international day of remembrance for pregnancy loss and infant death, which includes miscarriage, stillbirth, Sudden Infant Death Syndromeand any death of a newborn. title: underwater tank graveyard left after
story: NewsUnderwater tank graveyard left after controversial World War Two training exercise that changed course of warThe armoured vehicles sunk during Operation Smash – a huge training exercise held on a Dorset beach in April ShareCommentsByMichael Havis:,  OCT NewsThe tanks sank during a huge training exercise just weeks ahead of the Normandy landings "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Doomed tanks which may have “altered the course of history” by preventing a disastrous D-Day blunder have been revealed in stunning new images.The amphibious tanks sunk during Operation Smash – a huge training exercise held on a Dorset beach in April , just weeks ahead of the Normandy landingsSix lives were lost when the armoured vehicles sank but a lesson was learnt and, on D-Day , British and Canadian tanks were launched in shallow water, surviving to assist the assault.Nick Reed from The Isle of Purbeck Sub Aqua Club, which has launched a project to map the history of the seven sunken tanks, said the six soldiers lost did not die in vain. “Everybody says that Operation Smash was an absolute, complete disaster,” said Nick.  “Well,  tanks were launched and seven sank, so that means  got to shore in this exercise and from that the British learnt a lesson. “So when the British and Canadians launched their tanks on D-Day, they didn’t launch theirs offshore because it was too rough. “Whereas the Americans launched theirs five kilometres offshore.” The result of the American decision is well-known – just two of the  tanks initially deployed to storm Omaha beach made it ashore. Omaha would be the bloodiest of the D-Day beaches. “If we hadn’t got armoured support ashore on D-Day, our troops may not have established a beach head,” said Mr Reed. “So in many ways the sacrice of those six guys may have changed the course of World War Two – that’s the way we like to think of it. “Their sacrice wasn’t in vain, things were learnt from it and maybe that contributed to the success of D-Day.” Conditions at the e site off Studland Beach are notoriously changeable, making the sunken tanks a challenge to photograph. Worthless cowards decapitate World War I soldier memorial leaving it damaged beyond repairThe new images of them are thought to be the clearest ever taken. Paul Pettitt, who photographed the wrecks with his we Alison, said: “It’s rough as you like. “Those pictures were done over the course of a whole summer. Some days we went down and weren’t able to get anything. “The worst problem is the wind direction which kicks up the silt and sand on the bottom, and makes it go very gloomy down there. “But we got a lucky break one day when we got some really clear visibility and were able to get these pictures.” The tanks have also taken on new lives as articial reefs. “They’re absolutely full of wildle,” said Mr Reed. “There are several big conger eels living in one of the main tanks, there’s crabs, there’s lobsters, there’s big shoals of fish that swim around them. “That’s almost like a commemoration of the men themselves – men died on these tanks but these tanks now are providing le to the marine animals around the area.” The Duplex Drive Valentine tanks were equipped with a buoyant canvas screen which could be raised up around the tank and sat above the water line.  But soon after the tanks were launched the wind changed and water started to sweep over the top of the screens. “They were launched in suitable conditions but the wind blew up just after they were launched,” said Mr Reed. “The skirts, which provided the buoyancy, were only about a metre above the water – and obviously what keeps water out will keep water in. “So I think most of them were swamped and sank.” Earlier this year, a man believed to be the last-surviving soldier from Operation Smash – who is also a crew member from one of the doomed tanks – was located. Albert Price, , is now living in the West Midlands. It’s hoped he’ll be able to attend a  year commemoration of Operation Smash next year.

story: Kilmarnock winger Jordan Jones has been charged with ing by the Scottish Football Association.Jones has been hit with a notice of complaint over the penalty incident which led to his team’s winner at Dundee on Saturday and faces a two-match banthe case is proven.Dundee manager Neil McCann insisted there was no contact after Jones went down under the attention of Cammy Kerr before Eamonn Brophy netted from the spot to earn KIllie a - win.The SFA charge said: “No player shall cause a match official to make an incorrect decision and or support an error of judgement on the part of a match official by an act of simulation which results in that player’s team obtaining a substantial advantage.”Jones will face a hearing tomorrow.He will miss Ladbrokes Premiership games against St Mirren and Hamiltonthe charge is upheld.Dundee fans# group writes to top officials over referee Steven McLean#s links to Kilmarnock" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-fans-group-writes-to-top-officials-over-referee-steven-mcleans-links-to-kilmarnock embed # secretBSNUfzww" data-secret"BSNUfzww" width"" "" title"#Dundee fans# group writes to top officials over referee Steven McLean#s links to Kilmarnock# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: local out of school club boss grabbed vulnerable boy and called parent weird
story: The manager of an out of school club in Angus who taunted a boy by saying “no one likes you”, and verbally abused a parent in front of other children, has been struck off.The actions of Sharon Taylor, who was manager at Monieth Out of School Club, let to her being disciplined by the Scottish Social Services Council .A disciplinary hearing of the body heard Taylor grabbed the “vulnerable” boy by the arm and sat him on a chair then said: “You are not a very nice boy.”The SSSC’s fitness to practise  sitting in Dundee further found that in another incident, Taylor had taken hold of the same boy’s chin to turn it towards her while she reprimanded him.She was also criticised for describing the parent of one child as “weird” while in the presence of other children.The incidents happened in May and June .The  made an order removing Taylor’s registration from the part of the SSSC Register for Managers in a Day Care of Children Service.Finding that her fitness to practise was impaired by her misconduct, the  said: “Grabbing a vulnerable child by the arm and sitting them on a chair is intimidating and aggressive behaviour.”The Monieth club did not respond to a request for comment.

title: plan to turn former dundee bank into new coffee shop and takeaway
story: Plans have been lodged to turn a former bank into a coffee shop and takeaway.A change of use application to convert the former RBS building on Perth Road has been submitted to Dundee City Council by Jon Frullani Architects.The company lodged the application on behalf of city businessman Iqbal Jamal, of Jamal Property World on South Tay Street, who is keen to rent the property out as the West End’s newest eatery.Mr Frullani said: “This will be an excellent use of the former bank building.“Initial plans have been drawn up and there is room for  covers to be served.“Plans are at an early stage but it will be good to see that this empty building on Perth Road will be in use once more.“Once we get the necessary planning permission we will be able to go ahead with work to convert the former bank to create a cafe.”He said there was no date yet for when this would be completed or be ready to open to the public.Peter Menzies, chairman of West End Community Council, said he was delighted to hear about the plans.But he repeated calls made by other West Enders that the ATM at the building should be retained.“It’s great to hear this former bank building in a central location in the West End is to be brought back into use as a cafe,” Mr Menzies said.“The West End is becoming a great location for dining out and it’s great that there is to be a further venue for people to choose from.“It would be greatsomething could be worked out so that the ATM at the building could be retained as it is an important part of the local community.”RBS has lodged a separate planning application to remove the cash point when its lease expires next year.The bank had promised to retain the ATM following the closure of the branch in .There are three other cash machines nearby – at the Spar supermarket, the post office and at Premier Stores.An RBS spokeswoman said: “The ATM will be in service until spring next year.“Unfortunately, the leasehold for the ATM is coming to an end and we are required to remove it.“However, customers can readily access cash through our network of branch ATMs and for free via the Link network across Dundee.”

title: pub reveals when it hopes to open in dundee
story: A brewery is still hoping to open its new bar in Dundee before the end of the year.Work fitting out the proposed St Andrews Brewing Co venue on Shore Terrace began late last week.The Fe-based brewers had originally set the opening of the new bar, in the Caird Hall’s former arcade complex, for autumn this year.But the company was forced to reschedule after it was delayed getting on to the site to fit out the premises.A brewery spokesman said: “We are still hoping for a pre-Christmas opening.“We were delayed getting on site but now we’re in we would certainly hope to be open by December now.”The bar will be the fourth in the company’s portfolio, after a branch in St Andrews and two in Edinburgh.The pub is located next to the ill-fated Brassica restaurant, which opened to much fanfare in June but closed this month after staff walked out in a row over unpaid wages.The company behind the eatery, Tayone Food Ltd, entered administration last week.Dundee City Council, which owns the former City Arcades complex where Brassica is based, said it would be inappropriate to comment on the restaurant’s situation.

title: undertakers move into royal bank of scotland building in dundee
story: One of Dundee’s longest-established funeral directors is to take over the former RBS building in Stobswell.Grant Speedie, of James Ashton and Son on Cardean Street, confirmed that the firm will extend its business into the former bank building on Albert Street, which is just round the corner from the current premises.Mr Speedie said: “We can confirm that we have bought the former RBS building on Albert Street.“We get the keys on Thursday.“We will then go through the planning process with a view to beginning renovation work on the building next spring and would then hope to be in a position to open for business in summer.”Mr Speedie said that as part of its long-term plans for the former bank building, the firm had agreed with RBS that the cash machine located there would remain open for customers.He added: “We are delighted to be taking over this building to expand the service we can offer to our customers.“We are a long-established firm of funeral directors in Dundee and keen to stay in the Stobswell area.“We are happy to be part of the regeneration of Stobswell and hopeful that this move will also bring extra jobs to the local community.“We have agreed with RBS that we are happy to retain the ATM at the building and believe this is an important local facility for the community of Stobswell.“We have agreed that it will initially be retained for five years.”Colin Clement, chairman of Stobswell Community Forum, said he was happy to hear that Ashtons had agreed to retain the ATM at the building.“We fought to retain the bank but, when that didn’t happen, we sought an assurance that the ATM would be kept,” he said.“It has been out of order recently but I am delighted to hear it will be retained when Ashtons move into the building.”Local newsagent Anil Tewari said: “It is important that this ATM is retained. There are others close by, although this is the only one with easy parking for customers.”A spokesman for RBS said: “The ATM on Albert Street is being retained and we are actively working to bring it back into service, although there is no date as yet for the completion of the work.”

title: unicorn ceilidh raises 2k for dundee charity
story: A fundraising ceilidh held aboard HMS Unicorn raised more than £, for local charity, The Paul Young Fund.About  people attended the event, organised by Dundee Mountain Club.The club ran its own bar serving ale donated by Two Thirsty Men and cider donated by Cairn o’ Mohr fruit wineries.Local businesses also donated items for a raffle, which contributed to the £,. raised on the night.Paul, from Errol, was diagnosed with a brain tumour in .He set up the trust to find, fund and treat people living with brain tumours.It is a cause close to the hearts of those at Dundee Mountain Club, as one of its members was also diagnosed with a brain tumour a few years ago.The club is planning to make the ceilidh an annual event in Dundee’s calendar to raise funds for local causes.The club’s social secretary, Katrina Patrick, said: “We were blown away by the generosity.”
